prompt: Why do many corporate office jobs and behaviors seem designed more to preserve themselves than to produce meaningful work, and how can understanding this through evolutionary and biological analogies help improve organizational performance?
title: Do Corporate Jobs Evolve Like Living Organisms?
originalTitle: The Selfish Job: Evolutionary Insights into Corporate Behavior
socialQuestion: Do Corporate Jobs Evolve Like Living Organisms?
pullQuotes: "This perspective raises intriguing questions: Are some jobs adapted to thrive by appearing indispensable rather than by being efficient?"
"Just as genes propagate without conscious intent, a corporate role can take on a life of its own."
"Like DNA copying itself, a single role can replicate into an entire layer of management."
"An employee who openly challenges inefficient norms may find that such behavior threatens entrenched interests – and the organization’s ‘immune system’ might reject them."
"If the corporate environment rewards bureaucratic maneuvers, then indeed the fittest will be those who excel at that game."
sceneDescription: In a stark corporate boardroom, a group of identical-suited employees meticulously adjusts a large evolutionary chart pinned to the wall. The simple drawings progress from a single-celled creature up to a modern worker in a suit, whose figure is nearly engulfed by a tangled nest of policy binders. While one person carefully straightens the final image, the others hover around it, quietly ensuring their own place in the elaborate structure remains secure. The overall mood is calm, yet each figure appears subtly intent on self-preservation.
